192 181 Elsevier Sequoia S.A., Lausanne - Prince in The Netherlands HYDROGENATION OF I-REXENE BY RHODIUM CATALYSTS J. A_ PAJARES*, P_ REYES fnstilo de Cafdhsis y Petroleoquemica, C.S.d_C., Serrano. 119, 3fadrid (6) (SpaEn) L. A_ ORO and R. SARIEGO Beparfarrxento de Quimica fnorganica, Facultad de Ciencirs, Uniuersidad de Zaragoza, Saragossa (Spain) $I*mmary The catalytic activity for I-hexene hydrogenation (2Q C, Z atm) of several Rh-based catalysts (an homogeneous [Rh(NBB)(2-Me-py)2j C10,ss catalyst; the same complex supported on an acrylic resin, Duolite CC3; three Rh/duolite catalysts prepared by reduction of [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)zj C10 / duolite; and a series oRh/Si02, Rh/A1203 and Rh/Y zeolite catalysts, prepared following co-aventional impregnation or exchange procedures) has been measured- The metallic dispersion othe metal/support catalysts has been determined by several methods of selective chemisorption and by transmission electron microscopy; the Rh/duo'.ite system shows a narrow distribution ometal particle sizes between 1-8 and 25 A. The turnover numbers are very similar for Rh/Si02 and Rit/duolite catalysts. Samples of RhJA1203 show. smaller activity, probably due to a strong metal/support interaction. Much higher activity was shown by the Rh/Y zeolite system. The good c_ talytic activity of Rh/duolite makes this catalyst competitive with conventional rhodium supported catalysts, with the advantage of having a controlled, narrow-centered metal size distribution- FrEfaeoduction Although a variety of organic and inorganic materials can be used as supports for heterogenizing homogeneous catalysts, the use of ioz-exchange resins has scpreely been studied (? - 41. However, several polymer-bound rhodium catalysts have been prepare-d by decomposition of organometallic complexes , Sj , a method which is receiving increasing interest [7, 81. We study in this paper a resin-supported metal catalyst formed by treatment with molecular hydrogen of the rhodium(I) organic complex prepared Author W vi-horn correspondence should be addressed- 182 TABLE 1 Textural characteristics of the supports A1?03 Si02 Zeolite YT1a Duolite SBEL (m2 91) 149 128 786 0_0207 d,,, (g cm 3) 1.2.1 0_811 - 0.76 d= (g cm-3) 4.01 3.03 - 1.18 Pore volume, Va (cm3 g 1) 0.56 0_904 - - Mean pore diameter, d (:k) 75 141 - - by the interaction of [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2] C104 (NBD = 2,5-norbornadiene; 2-Me-py = 2-methyl-pyridine) with an ion-exchange resin (Duolite CC3)_ The catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of 1-hexane of this rhodium/duolite system is studied, as well as that of other analogous rhodium catalysts supported on silica, alumina and Y zeolite_ Some homogeneous hydrogenation data are also reported. Experimental Materials RhC13 aq., Rh = 40 wt- %, was obtained from Fluka AG, Buchs, Switzerland- All the solvents were dried and distilled immediately before use (acetone with 4 A molecular sieve, and ethanol with CaH2). Commercial olefins were deperoxidized by filtration through grade I neutral alumina. Gases, He, HZ, 12, 99.995 vo1.% pure, used in texture characterization, were supplied by S.E_O., Madrid- Before storage, they were passed through a purification train with 5 A molecular sieve from Union Carbide. The following materials were used as supports: (i) Duolite CC3, a cationic resin supplied in the acid (H*) form by DIA-PROSIM. Chemically, it is a carboxylic resin with acrylic backbone. It is fairly insoluble in water and has excellent mechanical and chemical resistance. Some of its characteristics, corresponding to the H' form, are given in Table 1. (ii) Girdler T-126 alumina, and BASF D-11-11 silica, had both a moderate specific surface and a ilegligable micropore contribution. The starting cylindrical pellets were ground and sieved to -0.59 + 0.42 mm. Both supports were heated 4 h. at 700 C in an air stream. The textural characteristics of the materials after this thermal treatment are given in Table 1. The fourth support used was NaY zeolite, Linde SK-Q0. Analysis of the nitrogen adsorption isotherm by the Dubinin-Raduskevich-Kaganer method [9] gave a specific surface, SDRK = 912 mz 971, with a micropore volume, V _ = 0.32 cm3 g-1. X-ray diffractograms [ 10] show a small degree of crys- 183 TABLE 2 Chemical analysis and dispersion of Rh/support catalysts Support R1Z conteut Dispersion Mean particle size (d) A1203 0.092 0.89 10 0.609 0.9? 10 2.45 0.42 21 SiO.s 0.117 0.38 24 0.252 0.62 15 0.685 0.81 11 1.35 0.84 11 Y-zeolite 0.285 0-23 39 0.391 0.23 40 0.534 0.49 18 Duolite CC3 0.052 0.49 18 0.091 0.35 25 0.170 0.35 25 [Rh(.1BD)(2-14ie-py)2]CIO,t/duolite, Rh (9o) 0_126 tallinity for the alumina, while those of Y zeolite correspond to the crystalline compound. Catalyst preparation [Rh(NEDJ(2Me py)2] Cl0_. The previously reporter compiex, [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2]C10 [11] was prepared by a simplified route: [RhCI(NBD)] 2 (0.05 mmol) dissolved in acetone, was stirred. for 30 min with AgC10 (0.10 mmol). After filtration of the AgCl formed, the solution was treated with an excess of 2-methylpyridine (2-Me-py), and after concentration the light-yellow complex was precipitated by addition of ether (yield: 87 o). [Rh(1VBDJ(2-Me py jz] CIO4lducilite. The Duolite CC3 resin, previously washed with water and methanol, was suspended in a solution of the [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2]Cl0t_ complex in absolute ethanol (1 - 4 X 10-3M)_ After 8 h of stirring the reddish product was filtered off and washed with ethanol. Rhodiumiduolt. The above mentioned product of the reaction of [Rh(NBD)(2-lfIe-py)2] ClO with duolite was suspended in ethanol and shaken for 7 h in the presence of hydrogen. The material slowly changes colour from red to green and finally to black. The rhodium concentration in these materials is reported below (Table 2). Rhodium/silica, Rhodium/alumina, Rhodium/.Y zeolite. Rh/Si02 and Rh/A1203 catalysts, with 0.1 - 2-5 wt-% Rh, were prepared by impregnation from ar aqueous RhC13 solution following the minimum volume method. 184 The operation was carried out in a rotavapor, usually over 10 g of support, heating to dryness at 70 C. The drying process was continued for 16 h. in an oven at 120 C. The impregnated material was decomposed bar a two-step reducing process in hydrogen flow, fi--st at 300 C for 2 h, and then at - 1~0 C for 2 h. The catalysts were cooled in a hydrogen flow to room temperature. Rh/Y zeolite samples were prepared through ionic exchange, at 50 C, of the sodium ions of the NaY zeolite with aqueous solutions of RhC13 (V 5CM3 0 )_ The zeolite had been dried at 500 C and then water stabilized in a closed vessel in the presence of NH4Cl-saturated solution. The final composition was Na_%(Al02)56(Si02)136 - 240H20_ Although the amount of support o be impregnated was weighed from this stabilized zeolite, the percentages of metal have been referred to the anhydrous zeolite_ Once exchanged, the material was filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried for 16 h at 120 C in an oven. The decomposition process was the same as described above. Equipment and rzethods Catalytic activicy_ The 1-Hydrogenation of the substrate was performed in a round-bottomed flask fitted with a side-arm silicone septum to allow injection and sampling for g.l.c. analysis. The flask was connected to a gas burette that allowed punping of the system and hydrogen dosing. The flask was shaken in a water thermostat. The catalyst solution (or suspension) was degassed in the hydrogenation flask and then H2 was admitted. After the prehydrogenation time the substrate solution was added. Acetone or ethanol ryas used as solvent. The hydrogenation rates were followed with a Perkin Elmer 3920-B gas-liquid chromatograph, using a 1/8 in o.d. X 4 m column packed with 15 wt.% 0,G'-oxydipropionitrile-Chromosorb W 80/100 mesh connected to a second 118 in o.d. X 4 m column packed with 20 wt.%o dinonyl phthalateChromosorb W 80/ 100 mesh. Chemical analysis. The Rh content was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy in a Perkin Elmer 360 apparatus, using a nitrous oxideacetylene flame, X = 399.2 nm and 0.7 mm slit. The chemical attack was made with 3890 FIF in a sand-bath until total dissolution of the support- The metallic component was dissolved in a sulphuric acid-hydrochloric acid mixture. The rhodium contents experimentally determined, as per cent, referred to the total metal plus anhydrous support mass, are given in Table 2. BET specific surface and active surface- Specific surfaces, S13ET N,, were determined in a Micromeritics 2100 apparatus, 16.2 A2 being taken for the cross-section of the adsorbed nitrogen molecule. The specific surface of Duolite CC3 was determined in the same apparatus, with krypton as adsorbate, taking 21.0 A2 for the krypton molecule cross-section and using the extrapolated vapour pressure of liquid Kr. Selective chemisorption o=' H2, 02, CO and Is2/02 titrations, in order to measure the specific metallic surface, were made in an adsorption volumetric apparatus [10] using an MKS E aratron 170 M-6A capacitance manometer as 185 pressure transducer. Particle size was calculated from the expression d = SjS, ez.p following Spenadel and Boudart [12j . Pore volume. Total pore volume, Vp = 1/dap - I/dr, was calculated from the experimentally measured real and apparent densities, determined by conventional helium and mercury volumetrics (Table 1). Pore size distribution was measured by mercury porosimetry, with an Aminco 60.000 porosimeter, and also from the total nitrogen adsorption isotherms obtained in the Micromeritics 21070 apparatus, following the Pierce and Brunauer `model-less' methods [10, 13] . 75-ansmission electron microscopy. TEM micrographs were taken in a Siemens Eliniskop 102 apparatus, working at 100 W, X 100 - 300 X 103. Rh/Si02 and Rh/A1203 samples were prepared for examination by an extractive replica method [141 , the ca-~alyst being metallized with a carbon layer, and then the support being extracted on a 2090 HF plus 8%o acetone aqueous solution. The metallic dispersion of Rh/zeolite and Rh/duolite was better studied by an ultramicrotome procedure, the sample being embedded in a Spurr resin [15J from which 300 - 800 A thick cuts were obtained with a diamond blade [16] . Infrared spectroscopy. IR spectra of Rh/support catalysts were obtained using the disk technique in a greaseless, vacuum-tight cell. The spectra were taken at rosin temperature with a double beam Perkin Elmer 125 apparatus. Results and discussion Characterization of Rh/support catalysts The experimentally determined rhodium contents for the different Rh/ support catalysts used in this work are given in Table 2, in which data on metallic dispersion and particle size are also included. Results for the Rh/A1203, 13 ,h/Si02 and Rh/zeolite systems were calculated from the mono layer for hydrogen chemisorption at room temperature, obtained by back extrapolation of the straight part of the isotherm (1 J0 - 300 mmHg hydro gen pressures). Pumping under high vacuum for at least 2 h at 530 C, or 16 h at 500 C, is necessary in order to reach a relatwely clean metal surface [10] . Other chemisorption-based experimental meth ads for the determination of metallic dispersion present some problems by comparison with hydrogen the.-isorption. Oxygen chemisorption at room temperature gives results quite near to those obtained from H2 chemisorption for the Rh/A1203 and Rh/Si02 catalyst series; similar results have been obtained recently by Fuentes and Figueras [171 . However, on RhIzeolite catalysts, the amount of chemisorbed oxygen is remarkably lower than that A hydrogen, this being probably due to penetration problems. Hydrogen/oxygen titratinns give ratios near 3 for the hydrogen chemisorbed on samples previously covered with oxygen, confirming the stoichiometry .q; i ; . il ar o 0 A N O O a 0 u W h 187 a b c4 c4tr G1 4 7 7 Q 17- 2C iL 20 - 0 20 40 0 20 40 Particle sizelA Particle sizeIA Fig. 2. Particle size distributions. (a) Rh 2.45,, o/A7203; (b) Rh 0.0527o/Duolite CC3. Rh-O + 3/2H2 - Rh-H + X120 found by Benson and Boudart on supported platinum [181 ; particle sizF3 calculated from hydrogen titration using this ratio are also very similar to those obtained from direct hydrogen chemisorption. Finally, i.r. spectra of Rh/support with chemisorbed CO show wide bands at 2030 cm-1 of single bonded CO, and at 1870 cm-1, typical of CO adsorbed to multicenters [19, 20] ; a smaller band at 2030 cm-" was also observed. While Wanke and Dougharty [21] in a previous work found CO:H ratios between 1 and 4, depending on particle size, in our case the stoichiometric ratio CO:H was always lower than I (between 0.41 and 0.72) for the different samples. Therefore thiz method is not suitable for the determination of metallic dispersion on supported rhodium catalysts [10, 22] . A t.e-rn. micrograph of an Rh 2.459'a/A1203 catalyst is given in Fig. I (a); the particle histogram can be seen in Fig. 2(a). The mean particle diameter, ds = EN;d13/E IJjd;z = 24 A, is slightly higher than that calculated from hydrogen chemisorption (21 A), which is consistent with the known tendency to measure predominantiy the larger particles when counting highdispersion catalysts by the former method. Chemisorption methods are not applicable to Rh/duolite catalysts, as the resin decomposes at the temperatures required in the cleaning treatment. Particle sizes for three Rh/duolite catalysts with different Rh contents, determined from t.e.m., are also collected in Table 2. A micrcgraph of an Rh 0.052%/duolite sample can! be seen in Fig. 1(b). The particle size distribution is quite narrow-centered (Fig. 2(b)) showing the potential of this preparation procedure for obtaining metal catalysts with fairly regular particle sizes [6, 7] . Small crystallites, probably aggregates of unreduced precursor molecules, are sparsely seen in the t.e.m. micrographs of Rh/duolite samples. This hypothesis is supported by the t.e.m. micrograph of th.e [Rh(hIBD) (2-Me-py)2] 0104/duolite (Fig. 3). 188 1~ 10Q0 aa Fig- 3. T.E.bi. micrograph of [Rh(NBD)(2-die-py)z]CIO.y/Duolite CC3. "Initial rate of appearance (no decomposition othe catalyst was observed in this stage). ***The rate of appearance of hexane ssrith the [Rh(NSD)(2-Me-py)Z]CIO.t/duolite catalyst is 1.1 (mol (mol Rh)-' (h)-1). Catalytic activity Acetone solutions of [Rh(NBh)(2-Me-py)2] C104 react with molecular hydrogen :..t atm,)spheric pressure and 20 C -,o give species which show iss modest activity for the hydrogenation of several unsaturated substrates (Table 3). In some cases some decomposition of the homogeneous catalyst to rhodium metal was observed, with a. corresponding increase in hydrogenation rate. When acetone suspensions of the [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2] C10 /duolite system were similarly treated, no decomposition was observed, but the rate of hydrogenation of 1-hexene was lower, (Z.1 mol (mol Rh)- (h)-l-). On the contrary, ethanol suspensions of the [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2] C104/duolite system react with hydrogen with slow formation of the metallic rhodium/ duolite system, characterized as described above*. Probably the decomposition process is favoured by the higher swelling power of the ethanol as corr:pared with that of acetone. The strong colour change, from yellow to red, upon interaction of [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2] C10,ss with duolite suggests that some chemical reaction occurs. In order to determine the type of rhodium complex formed in the so-called [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2] 0104/duolite system, we have studied the following reactions: [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2] C10 + Na(Me-COO) 1/2[Rh(Me-C00)(1'-TBD)] 2 + NaC10, 12Me-pyl/2[R1iC1(NBD)] 2 AgC104 Na(Me-COO ) Me ~ [Rh(NBDj(Me2C0)=] clod -> 1/2[Rh(Me-COO)(NBD)] 2. In fact, some previous studies [24] have shown 'hat the suspected yellow complex Rh(Me-COO)(NBD)(py) gives, at room temperature, the red compound [Rh(Me-COO)(NBD)]2. So we believe that the carboxylic units of the polymer should be bridging rhodium-norbornadiene groups, with the formation of [Rh(R-COa)(NBD)]2 dieters on the resin exchange. Results for the catalytic activity of the supported catalysts are given in Table 4. The rates at 20 C are given per gramme of catalyst, per gramme of rhodium metal and also as turnover -.umber (rate per minute per surface Rh atom). It can be seen that the Rh/zeolite catalysts exhibit the highest activity. The structure insensitive character of olefin hydrogenation reactions is EOIy established [2h, 26] . The turnover numbers found for Rh/Si02 and Rh/duolite catalysts are in agreement with this. In both cases the catalysts show a fairly good by drogenation activity; typical of rhodium metal, which *A similar behaviour has beer observed for the [Rh(N'BD)(Poly-CN)2] C10 complex, prepared by reaction of [Rh(NBD)(Me2Css)r]CLO [23] and Poly-CN (Poly(styrenl divinylbenzene) functionalized with CN groups). Within the R.h/Si02 series it seems that the catalytic activity diminishes for the lower particle size catalysts, with d < 15 A. The decrease of activity per site of very small particles for an easy reaction has recently been found by Figueras and coworkers [ I7 ] for benzene hydrogenation on Rh/A1203 catalysts. This is attributed to the formation of clusters, with lower activity, in the surface, rather than to a lower catalytic activity of the metal atoms in the edges, whose relative importance increases for the lower-sized metal particles [ 26, 2 7 ] . The lower turnover numbers of the Rh/A1203 catalysts are probably related to a strong metal/support interaction; it is known that rhodium readily reacts with alumina, diffusing into the subsurface region [281 . Alumina strongly reacts with noble metals and with metal oxides [29] , this fact determining some properties - resistance to sintering and also to reduction, etc. - that makes alumina the catalytic support most used at present [3 j . The higher activity of rhodium supported on Y zeolite for olefin hydrogenation and other reactions has also been observed by some authors [31, 32] . For benzene hydroaenation, similar results have been found on Pt/Y zeolite by Dalla a~etta and Boudart [33] , and on l'd/Y zealite by Figueras et al. [34] - Both authors base their explanation for the higher activity of these 191 catalysts, as compared with Rh/alumina or Rh/silica, on a high density of elecfxon-acceptor sites in the Rh/zeolite. Boudart [331 emphasizes the elec tron deficiency of platinum clusters as a result of partial electron transfer to the zeolite. Okamoto et al. [32] assign the high catal_Aic activity of Rh/Y zeolite to a combination of two types of centers: (i) surface rhodium metal atoms, and (ii) rhodium cations, mainly Rh(l), which are very active in hydrogenation and isomerization_ It is most unlikely to be the existence of Rh(l) in our experiments, after the -, trong reduction treatment (2 h at 550 C in hydrogen) undergone by the ca'alysts in the preparation procedure. It is more plausible to think of a reinforced activity in terms of Boudart's (loc_ cit.) ideas, based on the effect of the fraction of smaller rhodium aggregates, as could be inferred from the metal particle size distributions [101 . As expected, the catalytic activity of the homogeneous and heterogeneous complex is in agreement with the known fact that a mononuclear complex is able to catalyze a structure insensitive reaction [351 . The satisfactory results of catalytic activity obtained for the Rh/duolite system show this catalyst to be competitive with conventional silica- or alumina-supported metal catalysts. t. new advantage of these catalysts would be seen by study of structure sensitive reactions, where the preparation of catalysts, narrowly centered on a particular size (easier to obtain on a resin, because of its surface homogeneity) is essential. Finally, it is worth. mentioning that duohte resins do not seem to have particularly favourable properties as supports; perhaps it would be more promising to investigate resins with a developed macroporous system [36] _ References 1 Y. S Int_ Congr_ on Catalysis, Vol. 2, North-Holland, .Amsterdam, 1973, p. 1329. 34 F. Figueras, R. Gornez and M. Prizet, in W. M_ Meier and J. B_ Uytterioeven (edsj, :Zlolecular Sieve,., Adu. Chemistry Series 121. Americar. Chemical Society, Washington, 1973, n. 481'. 35 V_ Ponec, Inl_ J Quantum Chem_, 12 (Sup- 2) (1977) 1. 36 L_ A. Oro, R_ Sariego and J. A. Pajares, unpublished results- X244 8187006X 0304-5102(81)87006-X 10.1016/0304-5102(81)87006-X Hydrogenation of 1-hexene by rhodium catalysts J.A. Pajares ∗ P. Reyes Instituto de Catálisis y Petroleoquimica, C.S.I.C., Serrano, 119, Madrid (6) Spain * Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. L.A. Oro R. Sariego Departamento de Quimica Inorgánica, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de Zaragoza, Saragossa Spain The catalytic activity for 1-hexene hydrogenation (20 °C, 1 atm) of several Rh-based catalysts (an homogeneous [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2]ClO4 catalyst; the same complex supported on an acrylic resin, Duolite CC3; three Rh/duolite catalysts prepared by reduction of [Rh(NBD)(2-Me-py)2]ClO4/duolite; and a series of Rh/SiO2, Rh/Al2O3 and Rh/Y zeolite catalysts, prepared following conventional impregnation or exchange procedures) has been measured. The metallic dispersion of the metal/support catalysts has been determined by several methods of selective chemisorption and by transmission electron microscopy; the Rh/duolite system shows a narrow distribution of metal particle sizes between 18 and 25 Å. The turnover numbers are very similar for Rh/SiO2 and Rh/duolite catalysts. Samples of Rh/Al2O3 show smaller activity, probably due to a strong metal/support interaction. Much higher activity was shown by the Rh/Y zeolite system. The good catalytic activity of Rh/duolite makes this catalyst competitive with conventional rhodium supported catalysts, with the advantage of having a controlled, narrow-centered metal size distribution. The metallic dispersion of the metal/support catalysts has been determined by several methods of selective chemisorption and by transmission electron microscopy; the Rh/duolite system shows a narrow distribution of metal particle sizes between 18 and 25 Å. The turnover numbers are very similar for Rh/SiO2 and Rh/duolite catalysts. Samples of Rh/Al2O3 show smaller activity, probably due to a strong metal/support interaction. Much higher activity was shown by the Rh/Y zeolite system. The good catalytic activity of Rh/duolite makes this catalyst competitive with conventional rhodium supported catalysts, with the advantage of having a controlled, narrow-centered metal size distribution.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogenation of 1-hexene by rhodium catalysts
